Faculty of Materials Science and Chemistry China University of Geosciences Wuhan Hubei 430074 China Graphical abstract A controllable RCO-Ru-NVG heterostructure with engineered dual interfaces accelerates reaction kinetics and enhances durability for high-performance oxygen electrocatalysis. Zinc-air batteries (ZABs) are promising candidates for flexible electronics due to their high energy density and low cost. However, their development is hindered by the sluggish kinetics of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Herein, we present a novel heterostructured electrocatalyst composed of vertically aligned N-doped graphene (NVG) arrays anchored on Ru-doped ceria (RCO) nanofibers, synthesized via a one-step plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition process. Notably, during the plasma-enhanced driven NVG growth, Ru nanoparticles are spontaneously in-situ exsolved from the RCO lattice, forming a unique Ru@RCO-NVG heterostructure. Density functional theory calculations reveal that the Ru@RCO-NVG heterojunction induces interfacial electronic redistribution, thereby significantly lowering the energy barriers for both OER and ORR. Benefiting from the synergistic effects, the Ru@RCO-NVG catalyst exhibits exceptional intrinsic activity towards OER/ORR (an overpotential of 370 mV for OER at 10 mA cm−2 and a half-wave potential of 0.86 V for ORR), and higher all-solid-state flexible ZAB performance (peak power density of 286.1 mW cm−2), surpassing commercial Pt/C-IrO2 catalysts. This work not only advances the integration of synergistic graphene/ceria composites but also offers a promising strategy for designing efficient electrocatalysts for next-generation energy conversion technologies. Keywords Vertical N-doped graphene Doped ceria Exsolution Heterostructure Flexible zinc-air batteries 1 Introduction The rapid development of wearable electronics drives research frontiers in energy storage systems toward high-energy density and low-cost solutions. Zinc-air batteries (ZABs) have emerged as highly promising next-generation energy devices, boasting a high theoretical energy density of 1086 Wh kg−1 (equivalent to fivefold that of lithium-ion batteries), alongside environmental friendliness and abundant zinc resources [1,2]. However, the practical implementation of ZABs is severely hindered by sluggish bifunctional oxygen electrocatalytic kinetics at the air electrode. The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) involve complex four-electron transfer processes, leading to substantial overpotentials and energy losses [3,4]. While commercial Pt/C and IrO2-, RuO2-based catalysts exhibit superior oxygen electrocatalytic activity, their high cost, single-functionality, and poor cycling stability limit large-scale application [5,6]. To address these challenges, rare-earth metal oxides, particularly the most abundant and cost-effective cerium oxide (CeO2), have garnered significant attention as promising alternatives for large-scale deployment. The fluorite structure of CeO2 enables reversible modulation of Ce3+/Ce4+ redox couples, facilitating the generation of oxygen vacancies that promote oxygen ion migration [7,8]. Unlike conventional carbon supports, which suffer electrochemical oxidation and peroxide/radical attack under alkaline charge-discharge (especially at high charge voltage), leading to carbonate formation and surface-area loss, accelerating performance decay [9,10], CeO2 and doped CeO2 exhibit remarkable structural stability in alkaline and acidic electrolytes, with dissolution rates significantly lower than those of traditional carbon-based counterparts [11]. Furthermore, the Ce3+/Ce4+ redox couple in CeO2 can scavenge reactive oxygen species (e.g., *OH/*OOH) generated during ORR/OER, thereby suppressing support corrosion and enhancing the stabilization of metal nanoparticles [12,13]. Through strong metal-support interactions (M-O-Ce3+), CeO2 can also modulate the d-band center of supported metals, thereby tuning intermediate adsorption energies and enhancing overall catalytic activity [14]. For example, when serving as a support, CeO2 forms strong electronic coupling with metal nanoparticles (e.g., Ru, Pt), regulating the d-band center position of the metal via charge transfer and thereby optimizing the adsorption strength of reaction intermediates [15]. Nevertheless, pristine CeO2 suffers from inherently low electronic conductivity and an insufficient density of OER-relevant adsorption sites, motivating two complementary strategies: (i) introducing heteroatom dopants or constructing heterostructures to create vacancy-rich, electronically coupled interfaces, and (ii) integrating CeO2 with conductive scaffolds such as carbon nanotubes or graphene to accelerate charge/mass transport [16–18]. Among various dopants, ruthenium (Ru) is appealing as the least expensive platinum-group metal with near-optimal binding to *O/*OOH intermediates. Incorporating Ru into ceria lattice lowers oxygen-vacancy formation energies, optimizes the Ce3+/Ce4+ redox couple, and enhances bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysis [19–21]. However, conventional high-temperature synthesis often leads to Ru segregation, which diminishes the density of accessible Ru-O-Ce interfacial sites. Plasma-assisted synthesis methods, such as plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD), overcome the limitation by enabling low-temperature growth with rapid nucleation, mitigating thermally driven segregation and allowing precise interface engineering [22–24]. Moreover, PECVD can directly functionalize CeO2 surface with conductive carbon nanostructures during growth, enabling intimate integration of catalytic and conductive components and facilitating in-situ functionalization with conductive vertical graphene [25,26]. Herein, in this work, we employ PECVD for the in-situ growth of N-doped vertical graphene (NVG) arrays on Ce0.85Ru0.15O2− δ (RCO) nanofibers. During NVG growth, Ru nanoparticles in-situ exsolved from the RCO lattice, leading to a robust, integrated three-dimensional RCO-Ru-NVG heterostructure. PECVD affords exceptional process controllability and rapid deposition kinetics at reduced temperatures. The resulting vertical graphene arrays provide open ion/mass-transport channels and abundant edge-site exposure [27,28], while plasma-phase nitrogen enables simultaneous in-situ N-doping, which injects extra electrons into the graphene π-electron system, enhancing both overall conductivity and chemical stability [29]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal interfacial charge redistribution within Ru-O-Ce ensembles, enhancing the bifunctional catalytic activity for OER and ORR. When employed as a cathode catalyst, the resultant heterostructure delivers remarkable power density and exceptional cycling stability in flexible all-solid-state ZABs, highlighting its promise as an efficient and durable air cathode. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Structure and morphology characterization Fig. 1 (a) illustrates the plasma-assisted synthesis of the Ru@RCO-NVG heterostructure. Ce0.85Ru0.15O2− δ (RCO) nanofibers were firstly prepared via the electrostatic spinning method, then sintered and transferred to a radio frequency (RF) PECVD chamber. At 450 °C, the 500 W RF plasma discharge was applied to obtain the carbon and nitrogen radicals from the acetonitrile vapor, enabling directional growth of vertically aligned NVG arrays while simultaneously driving in-situ reduction and exsolution of Ru species from the RCO lattice. This process synergistically yields a well-defined three-dimensional (3D) heterostructure. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis (Fig. 1b, Figs. S1, and S2) shows that the as-synthesized RCO nanofibers retain a cubic fluorite structure (PDF#43-1002), with lattice parameters refined by the Rietveld method, confirming substitutional doping of Ru4+ into the CeO2 lattice. Notably, Ru@RCO-NVG exhibits additional diffraction peaks at 38.5°, 42.3°, and 44.2° (Fig. 1c), corresponding to the (100), (002), and (101) crystal planes of metallic Ru, respectively (PDF#65-7645). XRD patterns confirm the preservation of the CeO2 crystal structure following deposition. In addition, the lattice parameter of Ru@RCO-NVG (5.412 Å) is slightly larger than that of pristine RCO (5.409 Å), attributed to lattice expansion from numerous oxygen vacancies (VO) formation induced by reduction. Detailed refinement parameters are summarized in Table S1. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis determines the NVG mass ratio of Ru@RCO-NVG to be 11.22 wt% (Table S2). Raman spectroscopy analysis provides insight into structural defects (Fig. 1d). The characteristic peak located at 463.1 cm−1 originates from the F2g vibrational mode of the Ce–O8 cubic units in the CeO2 fluorite structure, while new emerged peaks at 638.5 and 695.1 cm−1 are associated with oxygen vacancies and asymmetric structures of Ru–O–Ce respectively, consistent with reports on defect-engineered ceria [30–32]. Furthermore, the appearance of characteristic peaks at 1346.9 cm−1 (D band), 1588.7 cm−1 (G band), and 2678.9 cm−1 (2D band) confirms the successful deposition of NVG. Significantly, a high I D/I G ratio of 1.65 indicates an abundant sp 3 carbon defect site [33,34]. The intensity of the 2D band suggests few-layer vertical graphene [35]. The coexistence of oxygen vacancies (638.5 cm−1) and graphene defects creates a synergistic conductive network, facilitating efficient charge transfer for electrocatalysis. The comparison of scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images reveals the morphology evolution. Compared to the pristine RCO nanofibers with smooth surfaces (Fig. 1e), Ru@RCO-NVG features vertically oriented NVG arrays with 50 nm-thick graphene layers formed after 1 min of deposition duration (Fig. 1f, g). Extended growth (2 min) leads to excessive coatings (Fig. S3), indicating superior nucleation kinetics of acetonitrile over traditional carbon sources [36,37]. The modification of NVG arrays reduces the contact angle from 131.6° to 83.9° (Fig. S4), significantly enhancing surface hydrophilicity [38]. This improved wettability facilitates deep electrolyte penetration into the 3D structure, thereby substantially increasing the number of accessible active sites. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis shows that the specific surface area increases from 7.97 m2 g−1 for pristine RCO to 10.69 m2 g−1 for Ru@RCO-NVG, accompanied by a pronounced enhancement in mesopore volume (Fig. S5). The hierarchical porous structure and well-integrated Ru-NVG heterointerfaces substantially maximize active site accessibility, promote efficient electrolyte/gas diffusion, and facilitate charge transfer, all of which are critical contributors to the enhanced bifunctional oxygen catalysis [39]. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was employed to characterize the microstructure of Ru@RCO-NVG composite. As shown in Fig. 2 (a, b) and Fig. S6(a), the RCO nanofiber core exhibits a typical cubic fluorite phase, with its surface uniformly encapsulated by a continuous NVG layer. High-magnification analysis (Fig. 2c and Fig. S6b) reveals distinct lattice fringes with a spacing of 0.338 nm corresponding to the (002) plane of graphene, while spacings of 0.191 and 0.163 nm are attributable to the (220) and (311) planes of the RCO, respectively. Critically, lattice spacings of 0.214 and 0.205 nm are observed at the NVG/RCO heterointerface, corresponding to the (002) and (101) planes of metallic Ru, respectively, consistent with XRD results. The size of Ru nanoparticles is confined within 3–4 nm, likely due to the suppression of excessive particle growth of the NVG layer via spatial confinement, where the simultaneously grown NVG imposes physical constraints on the migration and aggregation of exsolved Ru species. To validate the NVG-mediated regulation in Ru exsolution, the surface graphene layer was selectively exfoliated via prolonged ultrasonication. Fig. 2(d) and Fig. S6(c, d) reveal that the exsolved Ru nanoparticles retain a diameter of approximately 3 nm, with visible (101) lattice fringes confirming their metallic state. Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping (Fig. 2e) and line-scan profiles (Fig. 2f) further confirm a core-shell architecture with distinct elemental partitioning: C and N elements are enriched on the nanofiber surface, while Ru, Ce, and O are localized in the core. This unique core-shell heterostructure, where metallic Ru nanoparticles are embedded within oxygen-vacancy-rich RCO, integrates the redox activity of Ce3+/Ce4+ couples, the catalytic activity of metallic Ru, and the conductive NVG, establishing a multi-functional platform for oxygen electrocatalysis [19,40]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to probe surface chemical states modulated by NVG coating. The Ru 3p spectra of pristine RCO (Fig. 3 a) show only Ru4+ characteristic peaks (3p 3/2 at 462.8 eV and 3p 1/2 at 485.1 eV), while additional Ru0 peaks appeared after NVG growth, confirming the formation of metallic Ru nanoparticles. Notably, quantitative analysis of the Ce 3d spectra (Fig. 3b) reveals an increase in Ce3+ fraction from 15.58 % (RCO) to 35.55 % (Ru@RCO-NVG), accompanied by a decrease in Ce4+ content from 84.42 % to 64.45 %. This reduction in the average Ce valence (from 3.84 to 3.64) coincides with the formation of NVG-derived oxygen vacancies and the emergence of Ru0 species, suggesting their synergistic contribution to electronic structure optimization [41,42]. Deconvolution of O 1s spectra (Fig. 3c) identifies four components: lattice oxygen (O2−, 528.7 eV), highly oxidized oxygen (O2 2−/O−, 530.7 eV), hydroxyl/surface adsorbed oxygen (OH−/O2, 532.4 eV), and carbonates/physically adsorbed water (CO3 2−/H2O, 533.2 eV) [43]. Notably, the relative content of O2 2−/O− increases from 20.32 % in RCO to 28.28 % in Ru@RCO-NVG, corroborated by the enhanced signal at g = 2.003 value in electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) (Fig. 3d), indicating elevated oxygen vacancy concentration [44]. The oxygen vacancies serve as active sites for O2 adsorption/activation and optimize intermediate adsorption energy to accelerate OER/ORR kinetics [2,45,46]. The successful construction of NVG is further evidenced by the C 1s and N 1s spectra. Specifically, the deconvoluted C 1s spectrum (Fig. 3e) exhibits four components: sp 2-bonded carbon (283.9 eV), C–N bonds (284.8 eV), C–O bonds (286.03 eV), and C=O groups (288.6 eV). Correspondingly, the N 1s spectrum (Fig. 3f) reveals pyridinic N (397.8 eV), pyrrolic N (398.9 eV), graphitic N (399.8 eV), and oxidized N (400.4 eV) [29]. To further probe changes in the local coordination environment of Ce, X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) analyses were performed. Fig. 3(g) shows that the Ce L III-edge absorption threshold of Ru@RCO-NVG shifts towards lower energy compared to CeO2 and pristine RCO, indicating a reduced valence state of Ce cations. Quantitative calculations (Table S3) confirm a substantial increase in Ce3+ fraction, aligning well with XPS results. This reduction propensity signifies enhanced oxygen vacancy formation upon NVG integration. EXAFS fitting (Fig. 3h) shows that the Ce–O peak shifts from 2.29 Å (RCO) to 2.34 Å (Ru@RCO-NVG) with broadened width, indicating elongated Ce–O bonds and lattice disordering that facilitate reversible lattice oxygen detachment during oxygen catalysis [47]. Wavelet transform (WT) analysis (Fig. 3i and Fig. S7) clearly reveals attenuated Ce–O coordination intensity, reflecting NVG-induced lattice distortion. This synergy of bond elongation and oxygen vacancies provides an optimized electronic structure foundation for enhanced bifunctional catalysis [48,49]. 2.2 Bifunctional activity of ORR/OER Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves were measured in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte with iR corrected to evaluate the ORR activity. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), Ru@RCO-NVG displays an onset potential of 0.86 V and a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.75 V, significantly outperforming CeO2 (0.66 V), CeO2-NG (0.70 V), RCO (0.67 V), and Ru@RCO-NVG-2 (0.71 V). This enhancement is attributed to the 3D open structure constructed by NVG arrays, which significantly increases the specific surface area and facilitates oxygen adsorption/activation, as well as the confinement effect of NVG, which stabilizes the highly dispersed Ru nanoparticles. Notably, excessive growth (Ru@RCO-NVG-2) obscures active sites, validating the necessity of optimizing NVG layer thickness for maximal catalytic accessibility. Koutecký-Levich (K-L) analysis (Fig. 4b) reveals an electron transfer number of 3.39 for Ru@RCO-NVG, indicating a dominant 4e− pathway. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests (Fig. 4c) confirm that Ru@RCO-NVG possesses the lowest charge transfer resistance (R ct = 180 Ω) among all samples, reflecting its optimal electron transfer capability. For the OER performance, Ru@RCO-NVG exhibits a lower overpotential of 370 mV at 10 mA cm−2, significantly outperforming CeO2 (750 mV), RCO (640 mV), and commercial IrO2 (448 mV) (Fig. 4d). The Tafel slope of Ru@RCO-NVG (69 mV dec−1) is substantially lower than that of CeO2 (318 mV dec−1), RCO (210 mV dec−1), CeO2-NG (241 mV dec−1), and commercial IrO2 (91 mV dec−1) (Fig. 4e), confirming its favorable OER kinetics. The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) was evaluated by measuring the double-layer capacitance (C dl) via cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements (Fig. S8). As demonstrated in Fig. 4(f), the C dl value of Ru@RCO-NVG is 4.91 mF cm−2, 1.7 times higher than that of RCO (2.87 mF cm−2), confirming its high-specific-surface-area morphological characteristics. Intrinsic activity assessment further demonstrates superior mass activity (MA) and specific activity (SA) of Ru@RCO-NVG (Fig. S9). Turnover frequency (TOF), an intrinsic kinetic parameter, is derived from the current density at a fixed potential and the surface concentration or number of catalytically active metal sites. Crucially, the TOF of Ru@RCO-NVG rises sharply from 0.00539 s−1 (RCO) to 0.06126 s−1 (Fig. S10), directly confirming that the NVG growth-induced oxygen vacancies markedly increase the intrinsic activity. As summarized in Fig. 4(g), Ru@RCO-NVG achieves exceptional overall performance across five critical metrics, highlighting the comprehensive enhancement of bifunctional catalytic performance. In addition, Ru@RCO-NVG shows a low potential gap (ΔE = E j10 for OER − E 1/2 for ORR) of 0.85 V, outperforming most reported transition-metal-based bifunctional catalysts (Fig. S11). Chronopotentiometry (CP) curves at 10 mA cm−2 further demonstrate exceptional stability, with 92.27 % activity retention after 100 h of testing (Fig. 4h). This performance significantly outperforms both the RCO benchmark and recently reported bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts [50–53]. This durability originates from structural integrity of the NVG arrays, which mitigates degradation during sustained operation. XRD, SEM, and TEM analyses demonstrate the structural stability of the Ru@RCO-NVG electrode after stability testing. XRD patterns retain weak characteristic peaks of Ru nanoparticles without detectable RuO2 peaks (Fig. S12). The fibrous morphology remains intact (Fig. S13), while distinct lattice fringes for both RCO support and Ru nanoparticles are clearly resolved. TEM resolves distinct lattice fringes for both RCO and Ru nanoparticles, confirming crystallographic stability (Fig. S14). 2.3 Electrocatalytic mechanism exploration Fundamental insights into catalytic enhancement were established by integrating oxygen diffusion kinetics with density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Chronoamperometric analysis (Fig. 5 a) yields an oxygen diffusion coefficient (D O) of 8.2×10−11 cm2 s−1 for Ru@RCO-NVG, representing a 3.90-fold enhancement over CeO2 (2.1×10−11 cm2 s−1) and 2.56-fold enhancement over RCO (3.2×10−11 cm2 s−1). This acceleration of ion transport originates from NVG-induced oxygen vacancies, as corroborated by the minimized oxygen vacancy formation energy (E Vo = 1.657 eV). The reduced energy barrier facilitates rapid oxygen-ion migration, establishing efficient charge-compensation channels during OER/ORR processes [49]. Ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) measurements (Fig. 5b) reveal a significant decrease in the calculated work function (Φ) of Ru@RCO-NVG (Φ = 3.37 eV) compared to the RCO substrate (Φ = 4.33 eV). This reduction lowers the energy barrier for electron excitation under reaction conditions, corroborating the enhanced electrical conductivity observed after NVG deposition. Theoretically calculated results (Fig. 5c) further confirm this electronic modulation, providing a fundamental basis for the improved electrocatalytic performance. Differential charge density in Fig. 5(d) demonstrates interfacial electron redistribution. NVG confinement promotes charge transfer of 3.18 |e| to Ru nanoparticles (vs. freely precipitated Ru in Fig. S15). This is attributed to during the in-situ growth process, the intimate physical contact (van der Waals interaction) between Ru nanoparticles and NVG induces a contact potential difference that drives charge transfer. This results in the formation of a strongly coupled electron interaction interface, ultimately enhancing interfacial electronic coupling. In addition, there is 1.93 |e| that migrates from RCO to NVG, driving the RCO lattice into an electron-deficient oxidized state, thus triggering lattice oxygen loss and resulting in oxygen vacancy formation. Projected density of states (DOS) calculations (Fig. 5e and Fig. S16) reveals an upward shift of the O 2p band center from −2.76 eV (RCO) to −2.43 eV (Ru@RCO-NVG) (Fig. 5f). This shift closer to the Fermi level effectively reduces the electron transition barrier and intensifies Ru 4d-O 2p orbital hybridization (*p-d* coupling), thereby activating lattice oxygen. Noteworthy, the electron occupancy in the Ru dx 2 −y 2 orbital (e g orbital) increases (Fig. S17). According to the e g orbital filling theory, the higher e g occupancy optimizes the Ru–OH bond strength, weakening Ru–*OOH binding to accelerate desorption [54,55]. The OER pathway shown in Fig. 5(g) follows the adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM), consistent with RCO and Ru@RCO (Fig. S18). Gibbs free energy diagrams (Fig. 5h and Fig. S19) show that the rate-determining step (RDS) for both RCO and Ru@RCO is the transformation from *O to *OOH, with energy barriers of 0.821 and 0.509 eV, respectively, whereas the RDS for Ru@RCO-NVG is the transformation from *OH to *O (ΔG = 0.426 eV). The kinetic improvement originates primarily from the enhanced charge transfer through oxygen vacancy channels, facilitating proton-coupled electron transfer, and the optimized adsorption/desorption behavior of intermediates via e g orbital modulation, which collectively lowered the energy barrier for *OOH formation. 2.4 Electrochemical performance of ZABs To demonstrate the practical viability of Ru@RCO-NVG as a bifunctional catalyst, it was employed as the air electrode catalyst in rechargeable ZABs. The liquid ZAB exhibits a high open-circuit voltage (OCV) of 1.577 V (Fig. S20), remaining stable for over 24 h. The Ru@RCO-NVG-based ZAB achieves a record peak power density of 197.1 mW cm−2, significantly surpassing that of CeO2 (75.3 mW cm−2), RCO (132.9 mW cm−2), and Pt/C-IrO2 (82.9 mW cm−2) (Fig. S21). Galvanostatic discharge testing (Fig. S22) further confirms stable discharge plateaus of the Ru@RCO-NVG-based cathode from 1 to 20 mA cm−2, highlighting its exceptional high-rate capability. Furthermore, the Ru@RCO-NVG-based ZAB delivers a higher specific capacity of approximately 793 mAh gZn −1 at 10 mA cm−2, exceeding that of CeO2 and RCO-based batteries (Fig. S23). Long-term cycling at 10 mA cm−2 demonstrates exceptional stability over 400 h (Fig. S24) with minimal voltage decay (<9.8 %), demonstrating excellent cycling stability. Additionally, EIS under OCV, charging, and discharging states consistently shows the lowest interfacial impedance for Ru@RCO-NVG, indicating optimized reaction kinetics facilitated by efficient charge/mass transport (Fig. S25) [56]. To explore the feasibility of wearable electronics, all-solid-state flexible ZABs were fabricated using Ru@RCO-NVG as the cathode. As shown in Fig. S26, the flexible ZAB achieves a high OCV of 1.37 V. Its peak power density reaches 286.1 mW cm−2 at room temperature (∼25 °C, Fig. 6 a), significantly surpassing that of CeO2 (103.5 mW cm−2), RCO (131.5 mW cm−2), Pt/C-IrO2 (171.3 mW cm−2), NG (201.7 mW cm−2), CeO2-NG (115.8 mW cm−2), and RCO-NG (247.6 mW cm−2) (Fig. S27), and exceeding most cathodes reported for flexible ZABs (Table S5). Temperature adaptability tests (Fig. 6b) show that the peak power density reaches 222.2 and 141.8 mW cm−2 at 40 and 0 °C, respectively, suggesting robust performance over a wide temperature operational range. It is worth noting that the Ru@RCO-NVG catalyst exhibits superior performance at room temperature, achieving optimal capacity retention, rate capacity, and cycling life (Figs. S28–S30). Galvanostatic discharge curves (Fig. 6c) confirm significantly enhanced voltage plateau stability within the 1–10 mA cm−2, while a higher specific capacity of 779 mAh gZn −1 is maintained (Fig. 6d). As demonstrated in Fig. 6(e), the Ru@RCO-NVG-based flexible ZAB exhibits the lowest interfacial impedance, attributed to 3D charge transport pathways of NVG and Ru/VO synergy, significantly enhancing the interfacial reaction kinetics. Fig. S31 establishes Ru@RCO-NVG-based ZABs as delivering the highest power density and specific capacity among flexible/liquid configurations. Furthermore, the Ru@RCO-NVG-based flexible ZAB exhibits excellent cycling stability at 5 mA cm−2, with stable operation exceeding 40 h (Fig. 6f) with <22.1 % efficiency decay after 100 cycles, contrasting to the rapid degradation observed for the RCO-based battery (Fig. 6g). 3 Conclusions In summary, we develop a PECVD strategy for the rapid synthesis of NVG arrays modified RCO nanofibers heterostructure. This composite achieves exceptional bifunctional OER/ORR activity and kinetics by confining and stabilizing in-situ exsolved Ru nanoparticles, effectively suppressing aggregation and maximizing active site exposure. Meanwhile, oxygen vacancy engineering coupled with 3D hierarchical charge/mass transfer channels accelerates ion transport and O2 adsorption/desorption kinetics. When applied in zinc-air batteries, Ru@RCO-NVG cathode exhibits an ultrahigh power density and superior cycling stability, outperforming Pt/C-IrO2 benchmarks. Mechanistic insights further reveal electronic structure modulation at the Ru@RCO-NVG heterointerface, where p-d orbital hybridization shifts the O 2p band center toward Fermi level and e g orbital occupancy tuning optimizes *OOH desorption energy, facilitating OER kinetics. This design concept can be extended to the rational interface engineering of other heterostructure catalytic systems, offering a versatile strategy for high-performance energy conversion applications. coredata.dc:description: Zinc-air batteries (ZABs) are promising candidates for flexible electronics due to their high energy density and low cost. However, their development is hindered by the sluggish kinetics of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Herein, we present a novel heterostructured electrocatalyst composed of vertically aligned N-doped graphene (NVG) arrays anchored on Ru-doped ceria (RCO) nanofibers, synthesized via a one-step plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition process. Notably, during the plasma-enhanced driven NVG growth, Ru nanoparticles are spontaneously in-situ exsolved from the RCO lattice, forming a unique Ru@RCO-NVG heterostructure. Density functional theory calculations reveal that the Ru@RCO-NVG heterojunction induces interfacial electronic redistribution, thereby significantly lowering the energy barriers for both OER and ORR. Benefiting from the synergistic effects, the Ru@RCO-NVG catalyst exhibits exceptional intrinsic activity towards OER/ORR (an overpotential of 370 mV for OER at 10 mA cm−2 and a half-wave potential of 0.86 V for ORR), and higher all-solid-state flexible ZAB performance (peak power density of 286.1 mW cm−2), surpassing commercial Pt/C-IrO2 catalysts. This work not only advances the integration of synergistic graphene/ceria composites but also offers a promising strategy for designing efficient electrocatalysts for next-generation energy conversion technologies.
